name: Actor-observer bias
definition: tendency for explanations of other individuals' behaviors to overemphasize influence of their personality and underemphasize influence of their situation see also fundamental attribution error , and for explanations of one's own behaviors to do opposite
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Additive bias
definition: tendency to solve problems through addition, even when subtraction is better approach
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Agent detection
definition: inclination to presume purposeful intervention of sentient or intelligent agent
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ambiguity effect
definition: tendency to avoid options for which probability of favorable outcome is unknown
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Anchoringor focalism
definition: tendency to rely too heavily, or anchor , on one trait or piece of information when making decisions usually first piece of information acquired on subject
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Anthropocentric thinking
definition: tendency to use human analogies as basis for reasoning about other, less familiar, biological phenomena
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Anthropomorphism
definition: tendency to characterize animals, objects, and abstract concepts as possessing human-like traits, emotions, and intentions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Attentional bias
definition: tendency of perception to be affected by recurring thoughts
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Attribute substitution
definition: occurs when judgment has to be made of target attribute is computationally complex, and instead more easily calculated heuristic attribute is substituted
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Authority bias
definition: tendency to attribute greater accuracy to opinion of authority figure unrelated to its content and be more influenced by opinion
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Automation bias
definition: tendency to depend excessively on automated systems which can lead to erroneous automated information overriding correct decisions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Availability cascade
definition: self-reinforcing process which a collective belief gains more and more plausibility through its increasing repetition public discourse or repeat something long enough and it will become true
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Availability heuristic
definition: tendency to overestimate likelihood of events with greater availability memory, which can be influenced by how recent memories are or how unusual or emotionally charged they may be
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: BaaderMeinhof phenomenon
definition: frequency illusion is once something has been noticed then every instance of thing is noticed, leading to belief it has high frequency of occurrence a form of selection bias
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Backfire effect
definition: reaction to disconfirming evidence by strengthening one's previous beliefs
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Bandwagon effect
definition: tendency to do or believe things because many other people do or believe same
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Barnum effect
definition: observation individuals will give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality supposedly are tailored specifically for them, but are fact vague and general enough to apply to wide range of people
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Base rate fallacy
definition: tendency to ignore general information and focus on information only pertaining to specific case, even when general information is more important
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Base rate neglect
definition: tendency to ignore general information and focus on information only pertaining to specific case, even when general information is more important
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Belief bias
definition: effect where someone's evaluation of logical strength of argument is biased by believability of conclusion
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Belief Revision
definition: tendency to revise one's belief insufficiently when presented with new evidence
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ben Franklin effect
definition: person who has performed favor for someone is more likely to do another favor for person than they would be if they had received a favor from person
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Berkson paradox
definition: tendency to misinterpret statistical experiments involving conditional probabilities
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Bias blind spot
definition: tendency to see oneself as less biased than other people, or to be able to identify more cognitive biases others than oneself
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Bizarreness effect
definition: bizarre material is better remembered than common material
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Cheerleader effect
definition: tendency for people to appear more attractive group than isolation
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Choice-supportive bias
definition: tendency to remember one's choices as better than they actually were
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Clustering illusion
definition: tendency to overestimate importance of small runs, streaks, or clusters large samples of random data that is, seeing phantom patterns
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Common source bias
definition: common source bias csb refers to tendency to combine or compare research studies from same source, or from sources use same methodologies or data
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Compassion fade
definition: predisposition to behave more compassionately towards small number of identifiable victims than to large number of anonymous ones
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Confirmation bias
definition: tendency to search for, interpret, focus on and remember information way confirms one's preconceptions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Congruence bias
definition: tendency to test hypotheses exclusively through direct testing, instead of testing possible alternative hypotheses
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Conjunction fallacy
definition: tendency to assume specific conditions are more probable than more general version of those same conditions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Conservatismor Regressive bias
definition: tendency to remember high values and high likelihoods or probabilities or frequencies as lower than they actually were and low ones as higher than they actually were
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Conservatism bias
definition: tendency to revise one's belief insufficiently when presented with new evidence
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Consistency bias
definition: incorrectly remembering one's past attitudes and behaviour as resembling present attitudes and behaviour
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Context effect
definition: cognition and memory are dependent on context, such out-of-context memories are more difficult to retrieve than in-context memories e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Continued influence effect
definition: tendency to believe previously learned misinformation even after it has been corrected
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Contrast effect
definition: enhancement or reduction of certain stimulus' perception when compared with recently observed, contrasting object
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Courtesy bias
definition: tendency to give opinion is more socially correct than one's true opinion, so as to avoid offending anyone
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Cross-race effect
definition: tendency for people of one race to have difficulty identifying members of race other than their own
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Cryptomnesia
definition: form of misattribution where memory is mistaken for imagination, because there is no subjective experience of it being memory
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Curse of knowledge
definition: when better-informed people find it extremely difficult to think about problems from perspective of lesser-informed people
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Declinism
definition: predisposition to view past favorably rosy retrospection and future negatively
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Decoy effect
definition: preferences for either option or b change favor of option b when option c is presented, which is completely dominated by option b inferior all respects and partially dominated by option a
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Default effect
definition: when given choice between several options, tendency to favor default one
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Defensive attribution hypothesis
definition: attributing more blame to harm-doer as outcome becomes more severe or as personal or situational similarity to victim increases
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Denomination effect
definition: tendency to spend more money when it is denominated small amounts e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Diffusion of Responsibility
definition: people are less likely to take responsibility for action or inaction when others are present and individuals assume other are responsible for taking action or have already done so
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Disposition effect
definition: tendency to sell asset has accumulated value and resist selling asset has declined value
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Distinction bias
definition: tendency to view two options as more dissimilar when evaluating them simultaneously than when evaluating them separately
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Dread aversion
definition: just as losses yield double emotional impact of gains, dread yields double emotional impact of savouring
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
definition: tendency for unskilled individuals to overestimate their own ability and tendency for experts to underestimate their own ability
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Duration neglect
definition: neglect of duration of episode determining its value
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Egocentric bias
definition: recalling past self-serving manner, e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Empathy gap
definition: tendency to underestimate influence or strength of feelings, either oneself or others
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: End-of-history illusion
definition: age-independent belief one will change less future than one has past
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Endowment effect
definition: tendency for people to demand much more to give up object than they would be willing to pay to acquire it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Errors of Omission vs. Commission Bias
definition: people prefer errors they make through inaction over errors they may through direct and deliberate action
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Escalationofcommitment
definition: phenomenon where people justify increased investment decision, based on cumulative prior investment, despite new evidence suggesting decision was probably wrong
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Exaggerated expectation
definition: tendency to expect or predict more extreme outcomes than those outcomes actually happen
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: expectation bias
definition: tendency for experimenters to believe, certify, and publish data agree with their expectations for outcome of experiment, and to disbelieve, discard, or downgrade corresponding weightings for data appear to conflict with those expectations
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Experimenter's
definition: tendency for experimenters to believe, certify, and publish data agree with their expectations for outcome of experiment, and to disbelieve, discard, or downgrade corresponding weightings for data appear to conflict with those expectations
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Extrinsic incentives bias
definition: exception to the fundamental attribution error, when people view others as having situational extrinsic motivations and dispositional intrinsic motivations for oneself
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Fading affect bias
definition: bias which emotion associated with unpleasant memories fades more quickly than emotion associated with positive events
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: False consensus effect
definition: tendency for people to overestimate degree to which others agree with them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: False memory
definition: form of misattribution where imagination is mistaken for memory
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: False uniqueness bias
definition: tendency of people to see their projects and themselves as more singular than they actually are
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Forer effect
definition: observation individuals will give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality supposedly are tailored specifically for them, but are fact vague and general enough to apply to wide range of people
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Form function attribution bias
definition: in humanrobot interaction, tendency of people to make systematic errors when interacting with robot
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Framing effect
definition: drawing different conclusions from same information, depending on how information is presented
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Frequency illusion
definition: frequency illusion is once something has been noticed then every instance of thing is noticed, leading to belief it has high frequency of occurrence a form of selection bias
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Functional fixedness
definition: limits person to using object only way it is traditionally used
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Fundamental attribution error
definition: tendency for people to over-emphasize personality-based explanations for behaviors observed others while under-emphasizing role and power of situational influences on same behavior1 see also actor-observer bias, group attribution error, positivity effect
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Gambler fallacy
definition: tendency to think future probabilities are altered by past events, when reality they are unchanged
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Gender bias
definition: widely held set of implicit biases discriminate against gender
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Generation effect Self-generation effect
definition: self-generated information is remembered best
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Gettier Problems
definition: can conclusions count as knowledge if they were formed without right information? is belief justified if it is believed for invalid reasons? if premise is faulty?
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Google effect
definition: tendency to forget information can be found readily online by using internet search engines
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Group attribution error
definition: biased belief characteristics of individual group member are reflective of group as whole or tendency to assume group decision outcomes reflect preferences of group members, even when information is available clearly suggests otherwise
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Groupthink
definition: psychological phenomenon that occurs within a group of people in which desire for harmony or conformity group results irrational or dysfunctional decision-making outcome
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Halo effect
definition: tendency for person's positive or negative traits to spill over from one personality area to another others' perceptions of them see also physical attractiveness stereotype
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Hardeasy effect
definition: tendency to overestimate one's ability to accomplish hard tasks, and underestimate one's ability to accomplish easy tasks
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Hindsight bias
definition: sometimes called i-knew-it-all-along effect, tendency to see past events as being predictable1 at time those events happened
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Hostile attribution bias
definition: hostile attribution bias is tendency to interpret others' behaviors as having hostile intent, even when behavior is ambiguous or benign
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Hot-hand fallacy
definition: hot-hand fallacy also known as hot hand phenomenon or hot hand  is belief person who has experienced success with random event has greater chance of further success additional attempts
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Humor effect
definition: humorous items are more easily remembered than non-humorous ones, which might be explained by distinctiveness of humor, increased cognitive processing time to understand humor, or emotional arousal caused by humor
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Hyperbolic discounting
definition: discounting is tendency for people to have stronger preference for more immediate payoffs relative to later payoffs
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: IKEA effect
definition: tendency for people to place disproportionately high value on objects they partially assembled themselves, such as furniture from ikea, regardless of quality of end product
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illicit transference
definition: occurs when term distributive referring to every member of class and collective referring to class itself as whole sense are treated as equivalent
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusion of asymmetric insight
definition: people perceive their knowledge of their peers to surpass their peers' knowledge of them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusion of control
definition: tendency to overestimate one's degree of influence over other external events
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusion of transparency
definition: tendency for people to overestimate degree to which their personal mental state is known by others, and to overestimate how well they understand others' personal mental states
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusion of validity
definition: overestimating accuracy of one's judgments, especially when available information is consistent or inter-correlated
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusory correlation
definition: inaccurately perceiving relationship between two unrelated events
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusory superiority
definition: overestimating one's desirable qualities, and underestimating undesirable qualities, relative to other people
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Illusory truth effect
definition: tendency to believe statement is true if it is easier to process, or if it has been stated multiple times, regardless of its actual veracity
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Impact bias
definition: tendency to overestimate length or intensity of impact of future feeling states
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Implicit association
definition: speed with which people can match words depends on how closely they are associated
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Imposter Syndrome
definition: people doubt their accomplishments and have persistent, often internalized fear of being exposed as “fraud“ and proof of success is dismissed as luck, timing, or as result of deceit
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Information bias
definition: tendency to seek information even when it cannot affect action
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ingroup bias
definition: tendency for people to give preferential treatment to others they perceive to be members of their own groups
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Insensitivity to sample size
definition: tendency to under-expect variation small samples
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Intentionality bias
definition: tendency to judge human action to be intentional rather than accidental
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Interoceptive bias
definition: tendency for sensory input about body itself to affect one's judgement about external, unrelated circumstances
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Irrational escalation
definition: phenomenon where people justify increased investment decision, based on cumulative prior investment, despite new evidence suggesting decision was probably wrong
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Just-world hypothesis
definition: tendency for people to want to believe world is fundamentally just, causing them to rationalize otherwise inexplicable injustice as deserved by victim s
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Lag effect
definition: phenomenon whereby learning is greater when studying is spread out over time, as opposed to studying same amount of time single session
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Law of the instrument
definition: over-reliance on familiar tool or methods, ignoring or under-valuing alternative approaches
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Learned Helplessness
definition: when people accept and remain passive negative situations despite their clear ability to change them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Less-is-better effect
definition: tendency to prefer smaller set to larger set judged separately, but not jointly
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Leveling and sharpening
definition: memory distortions introduced by loss of details recollection over time, often concurrent with sharpening or selective recollection of certain details take on exaggerated significance relation to details or aspects of experience lost through leveling
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Levels-of-processing effect
definition: different methods of encoding information into memory have different levels of effectiveness
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: List-length effect
definition: smaller percentage of items are remembered longer list, but as length of list increases, absolute number of items remembered increases as well
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Loss aversion
definition: perceived disutility of giving up object is greater than utility associated with acquiring it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Mere exposure effect
definition: tendency to express undue liking for things merely because of familiarity with them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Misinformation effect
definition: memory becoming less accurate because of interference from post-event information
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Modality effect
definition: memory recall is higher for last items of list when list items were received via speech than when they were received through writing
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Money illusion
definition: tendency to concentrate on nominal value face value of money rather than its value terms of purchasing power
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Mood-congruent memory bias
definition: improved recall of information congruent with one's current mood
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Moral credential effect
definition: occurs when someone who does something good gives themselves permission to be less good future
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Moral luck
definition: tendency for people to ascribe greater or lesser moral standing based on outcome of event
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Naïve cynicism
definition: expecting more egocentric bias in others than oneself
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Naïve realism
definition: belief we see reality as it really is  objectively and without bias; facts are plain for all to see; rational people will agree with us; and those who don't are either uninformed, lazy, irrational, or biased
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Negativity biasor Negativity effect
definition: psychological phenomenon by which humans have greater recall of unpleasant memories compared with positive memories
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Neglect of probability
definition: tendency to completely disregard probability when making decision under uncertainty
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Next-in-line effect
definition: when taking turns speaking group using predetermined order e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Non-adaptive choice switching
definition: after experiencing bad outcome with decision problem, tendency to avoid choice previously made when faced with same decision problem again, even though choice was optimal
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Normalcy bias
definition: refusal to plan for, or react to, disaster which has never happened before
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Not invented here
definition: aversion to contact with or use of products, research, standards, or knowledge developed outside group
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Observer-expectancy effect
definition: when researcher expects given result and therefore unconsciously manipulates experiment or misinterprets data order to find it see also subject-expectancy effect
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Omission bias
definition: tendency to judge harmful actions commissions as worse, or less moral, than equally harmful inactions omissions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Optimism bias
definition: tendency to be over-optimistic, underestimating greatly probability of undesirable outcomes and overestimating favorable and pleasing outcomes see also wishful thinking, valence effect, positive outcome bias
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ostracism
definition: when people are ostracized, their brain’s pain center registers physical pain, and they are more likely to engage behaviors increase inclusion by mimicking, complying, obeying orders, cooperating or expressing attraction
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ostrich effect
definition: ignoring obvious negative situation
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Outcome bias
definition: tendency to judge decision by its eventual outcome instead of based on quality of decision at time it was made
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Outgroup homogeneity bias
definition: individuals see members of their own group as being relatively more varied than members of other groups
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Overconfidence effect
definition: excessive confidence one's own answers to questions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pareidolia
definition: vague and random stimulus often image or sound is perceived as significant, e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Parkinson law of triviality
definition: tendency to give disproportionate weight to trivial issues
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Part-list cueing effect
definition: being shown some items from list and later retrieving one item causes it to become harder to retrieve other items
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Peakend rule
definition: people seem to perceive not sum of experience but average of how it was at its peak e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: personification
definition: tendency to characterize animals, objects, and abstract concepts as possessing human-like traits, emotions, and intentions
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pessimism bias
definition: tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate likelihood of negative things happening to them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Picture superiority effect
definition: notion concepts are learned by viewing pictures are more easily and frequently recalled than are concepts are learned by viewing their written word form counterparts
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Planck’s Principle
definition: new scientific truth triumphs not by convincing its opponents, but rather because its opponents eventually die and new generation grows up is familiar with it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Plan continuation bias
definition: failure to recognize original plan of action is no longer appropriate for changing situation or for situation is different than anticipated
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Planning fallacy
definition: tendency to underestimate one's own task-completion times
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Plant blindness
definition: tendency to ignore plants their environment and failure to recognize and appreciate utility of plants to life on earth
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pluralistic Ignorance
definition: occurs when majority of group members privately reject idea, but incorrectly assume most others accept it, and therefore go along with it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Positivity effect Socioemotional selectivity theory
definition: older adults favor positive over negative information their memories
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Present bias
definition: tendency of people to give stronger weight to payoffs are closer to present time when considering trade-offs between two future moments
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Prevention bias
definition: when investing money to protect against risks, decision makers perceive dollar spent on prevention buys more security than dollar spent on timely detection and response, even when investing either option is equally effective
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Probability matching
definition: sub-optimal matching of probability of choices with probability of reward stochastic context
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Processing difficulty effect
definition: information takes longer to read and is thought about more processed with more difficulty is more easily remembered
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pro-innovation bias
definition: tendency to have excessive optimism towards invention or innovation's usefulness throughout society, while often failing to identify its limitations and weaknesses
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Projection bias
definition: tendency to overestimate how much our future selves share one's current preferences, thoughts and values, thus leading to sub-optimal choices
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Proportionality bias
definition: our innate tendency to assume big events have big causes, may also explain our tendency to accept conspiracy theories
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pseudocertainty effect
definition: tendency to make risk-averse choices if expected outcome is positive, but make risk-seeking choices to avoid negative outcomes
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Puritanical bias
definition: refers to tendency to attribute cause of undesirable outcome or wrongdoing by individual to moral deficiency or lack of self-control rather than taking into account impact of broader societal determinants
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Pygmalion effect
definition: phenomenon whereby others' expectations of target person affect target person's performance
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Reactance
definition: urge to do opposite of what someone wants you to do out of need to resist perceived attempt to constrain your freedom of choice see also reverse psychology
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Reactive devaluation
definition: devaluing proposals only because they purportedly originated with adversary
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Recency illusion
definition: illusion phenomenon one has noticed only recently is itself recent
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Reminiscence bump
definition: recalling of more personal events from adolescence and early adulthood than personal events from other lifetime periods
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Restraint bias
definition: tendency to overestimate one's ability to show restraint face of temptation
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Rhyme as reason effect
definition: rhyming statements are perceived as more truthful
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Risk compensation or Peltzman effect
definition: tendency to take greater risks when perceived safety increases
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Salience bias
definition: tendency to focus on items are more prominent or emotionally striking and ignore those are unremarkable, even though difference is often irrelevant by objective standards
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: scope insensitivity
definition: tendency to be insensitive to size of problem when evaluating it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Scope neglect
definition: tendency to be insensitive to size of problem when evaluating it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Selection bias
definition: happens when members of a statistical sample are not chosen completely at random, which leads to sample not being representative of population
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Selective perception
definition: tendency for expectations to affect perception
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Self-relevance effect
definition: memories relating to self are better recalled than similar information relating to others
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Self-serving bias
definition: tendency to claim more responsibility for successes than failures
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Semmelweis reflex
definition: tendency to reject new evidence contradicts paradigm
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Serial position effect
definition: items near end of sequence are easiest to recall, followed by items at beginning of sequence; items middle are least likely to be remembered
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Sexual overperception bias or Sexual underperception bias
definition: tendency to over- or underestimate sexual interest of another person oneself
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Shared information bias
definition: known as tendency for group members to spend more time and energy discussing information all members are already familiar with i
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Social comparison bias
definition: tendency, when making decisions, to favour potential candidates who don't compete with one's own particular strengths
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Social desirability bias
definition: tendency to over-report socially desirable characteristics or behaviours oneself and under-report socially undesirable characteristics or behaviours
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Source confusion
definition: confusing episodic memories with other information, creating distorted memories
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Spacing effect
definition: information is better recalled if exposure to it is repeated over long span of time rather than short one
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Spotlight effect
definition: tendency to overestimate amount other people notice your appearance or behavior
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Status quo bias
definition: tendency to like things to stay relatively same see also loss aversion, endowment effect, and system justification
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Stereotypical bias
definition: memory distorted towards stereotypes e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Stereotyping
definition: expecting member of group to have certain characteristics without having actual information about individual
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Subadditivity effect
definition: tendency to judge probability of whole to be less than probabilities of parts
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Subjective validation
definition: perception something is true if subject's belief demands it to be true
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Suffix effect
definition: diminishment of recency effect because sound item is appended to list subject is not required to recall
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Suggestibility
definition: form of misattribution where ideas suggested by questioner are mistaken for memory
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Surrogation
definition: losing sight of strategic construct measure is intended to represent, and subsequently acting as though measure is construct of interest
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Survivorship bias
definition: concentrating on people or things survived some process and inadvertently overlooking those didn't because of their lack of visibility
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Systematic bias
definition: judgement arises when targets of differentiating judgement become subject to effects of regression are not equivalent
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: System justification
definition: tendency to defend and bolster status quo
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Tachypsychia
definition: when time perceived by individual either lengthens, making events appear to slow down, or contracts
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Telescoping effect
definition: tendency to displace recent events backwards time and remote events forward time, so recent events appear more remote, and remote events, more recent
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Testing effect
definition: fact you more easily remember information you have read by rewriting it instead of rereading it
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Third-person effect
definition: hypothesized tendency to believe mass communicated media messages have greater effect on others than on themselves
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Time-saving bias
definition: underestimations of time could be saved or lost when increasing or decreasing from relatively low speed and overestimations of time could be saved or lost when increasing or decreasing from relatively high speed
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Tip of the tonguephenomenon
definition: when subject is able to recall parts of item, or related information, but is frustratingly unable to recall whole item
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Trait ascription bias
definition: tendency for people to view themselves as relatively variable terms of personality, behavior, and mood while viewing others as much more predictable
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Travis Syndrome
definition: overestimating significance of present
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Ultimate attribution error
definition: similar to fundamental attribution error, error person is likely to make internal attribution to entire group instead of individuals within group
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Unconscious bias
definition: also known as implicit biases, are underlying attitudes and stereotypes people unconsciously attribute to another person or group of people affect how they understand and engage with them
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Unit bias
definition: standard suggested amount of consumption e
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Verbatim effect
definition: gist of what someone has said is better remembered than verbatim wording
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: von Restorff effect
definition: item sticks out is more likely to be remembered than other items
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: WeberFechner law
definition: difficulty comparing small differences large quantities
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Well travelled road effect
definition: underestimation of duration taken to traverse oft-travelled routes and overestimation of duration taken to traverse less familiar routes
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Women are wonderful effect
definition: tendency to associate more positive attributes with women than with men
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Worse-than-average effect
definition: tendency to believe ourselves to be worse than others at tasks which are difficult
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Zeigarnik effect
definition: uncompleted or interrupted tasks are remembered better than completed ones
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Zero-risk bias
definition: preference for reducing small risk to zero over greater reduction larger risk
:LABEL: CognitiveBias

name: Zero-sum bias
definition: bias whereby situation is incorrectly perceived to be like zero-sum game i
:LABEL: CognitiveBias
